CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, January 13, 1962, pg. A15, reads: "Miss Cordell Evans Makes Lovely Ethnan Temple Bride - Mrs. Linval O. Williamson...lovely bride." Accompanying article reads: "Ethnan Temple was the setting for the wedding which united Miss Cordell Evans of Pittsburgh and Linval O. Williamson of Jamaica West Indies.  The bride was a vision of loveliness in an exquisite gown of ivory bouquet taffeta and re-embroidered Alencon lace.  The batteau neckline of the gown was sprinkled with imported beads and pearls.  The bouffant skirt with tucked side drapings, was styled with a large silk rose at the back and ended in a chapel train.  Her veil was a finger-tip mantilla of imported tulle, and she carried a bouquet of white mums centered with a white orchid.  Mrs. Ann Galley served as matron of honor, Miss Rosalie Evans, younger sister of the bride, was maid of honor.  Other bridal attendants were: the Misses Ruth Mosby, Helen George and Mrs. Nelson Bliss.  They wore cherry-pink taffeta gowns with matching headdresses and carried white mum bouquets.  John Skinner, brother-in-law of the groom, was best man.  Ushers were: John Hall, William Anderson, Robert Parker and Phillips Lewis.  Elder Nelson Bliss officiated at the rites, and nuptial music was furnished by Mrs. Dorothy May of Pittsburgh and Patricia Terrell of Cleveland, Ohio.  Mrs. Paul Bruns was at the organ and Mrs. Robert Smith at the piano.  The bride was given in marriage by her father.  A reception for the newlyweds was held at the Shadyside Seventh-Day Adventist Church.  Serving as aids were: the Misses Norwida Marshall and Janet Mosby, and Mmes. Linda Green, Flossie Johnson, Janet Lawson and Helen Lewis.  Pre-nuptial affairs included a bachelor dinner at the groom's quarters on Centre Avenue.  After a short honeymoon and leave, the bride will return to her teaching duties at the Oakwood College in Alabama, and the groom resumed his responsibilities as principal-teacher of Ethnan Temple Intermediate School of Pittsburgh."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of wedding party including groom Linval O. Williamson, and bride Cordell Evans Williamson wearing full gown with long lace sleeves, posed in front of altar in Ethnan Temple Seventh Day Adventist Church

cutline: Miss Cordell Evans Makes Lovely Ethnan Temple Bride - Mrs. Linval O. Williamson...lovely bride." Accompanying article reads: "Ethnan Temple was the setting for the wedding which united Miss Cordell Evans of Pittsburgh and Linval O. Williamson of Jamaica West Indies.  The bride was a vision of loveliness in an exquisite gown of ivory bouquet taffeta and re-embroidered Alencon lace.  The batteau neckline of the gown was sprinkled with imported beads and pearls.  The bouffant skirt with tucked side drapings, was styled with a large silk rose at the back and ended in a chapel train.  Her veil was a finger-tip mantilla of imported tulle, and she carried a bouquet of white mums centered with a white orchid.  Mrs. Ann Galley served as matron of honor, Miss Rosalie Evans, younger sister of the bride, was maid of honor.  Other bridal attendants were: the Misses Ruth Mosby, Helen George and Mrs. Nelson Bliss.  They wore cherry-pink taffeta gowns with matching headdresses and carried white mum bouquets.  John Skinner, brother-in-law of the groom, was best man.  Ushers were: John Hall, William Anderson, Robert Parker and Phillips Lewis.  Elder Nelson Bliss officiated at the rites, and nuptial music was furnished by Mrs. Dorothy May of Pittsburgh and Patricia Terrell of Cleveland, Ohio.  Mrs. Paul Bruns was at the organ and Mrs. Robert Smith at the piano.  The bride was given in marriage by her father.  A reception for the newlyweds was held at the Shadyside Seventh-Day Adventist Church.  Serving as aids were: the Misses Norwida Marshall and Janet Mosby, and Mmes. Linda Green, Flossie Johnson, Janet Lawson and Helen Lewis.  Pre-nuptial affairs included a bachelor dinner at the groom's quarters on Centre Avenue.  After a short honeymoon and leave, the bride will return to her teaching duties at the Oakwood College in Alabama, and the groom resumed his responsibilities as principal-teacher of Ethnan Temple Intermediate School of Pittsburgh.
